description:
Multiyear partnerships nurture trust as relationships between funders and nonprofits deepen over time and a mutual understanding of both stakeholders’ needs is built. Engaging in longer-term partnerships allows funders to move from being only grantmakers to playing the role of advisors. A multiyear approach can help to increase focus on creating lasting change over immediate and short-term outputs. Additionally, it enables stability for nonprofits to plan for the future.

For funders, multiyear partnerships also simplify grantmaking, reducing the time spent on scouting new nonprofit partners and projects and helping funders gain a deeper understanding of social issues. Partnerships can enrich programme team members, who are able to invest more time and effort in understanding a nonprofit’s needs and support the nonprofit in delivering on its intended impact. Here’s where your organisation ranks on several dimensions of multiyear partnerships.
name: pm84tbr7tr

recommended_actions.actions:
1. If lack of clear guidelines is a challenge:
  2. Arrive at internal consensus on the need for adopting multiyear partnerships by highlighting the benefits of the approach to key decision makers.
  3. Define criteria which can help reduce subjectivity in entering multiyear relationships and communicate this to the relevant internal stakeholders.
  4. Document and circulate the organisation’s philosophy and approach internally.
  5.   If the cause is a lack of alignment on guidelines:
  6. Present senior leadership and the board with research supporting multiyear grantmaking and showcase examples from funders and nonprofits that have fostered multiyear partnerships.
  7. Identify potential champions and seek their support in driving alignment.
  8. Reinforce the belief by sharing the benefits accruing to the organisation through multiyear partnerships.
recommended_actions.title: Policy guidelines

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Evaluate your current funding portfolio to assess if the cause is fewer multiyear partnerships or a lower allocation of funding to such partnerships.
  2. If the cause is fewer multiyear partnerships, identify nonprofits in your current portfolio which meet the criteria for multiyear partnerships and engage in conversations accordingly.
  3. If the cause is lower allocation of funding to such partnerships, assess the reason for low allocation to these nonprofits and if there are options to deepen engagement with them.


  1. Develop annual plans targeting higher allocation to multiyear partnerships with rationale and approaches to be adopted.
recommended_actions.title: Annual budget allocation

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Engage with nonprofit partners to understand the barriers they perceive in seeking multiyear partnerships.


  1. Clearly define realistic criteria (e.g. mission alignment, demonstrated impact, etc.) for nonprofit selection. The criteria should guide decision making and ensure shared understanding and transparency amongst your organisation’s staff and nonprofit partners.

﻿

  1. Assess your expectations and whether they might be too stringent and need modification. Assess the parameters which act as a hurdle for qualification for multiyear partnerships and evaluate if they are objectively developed and grounded in your context and realities.
recommended_actions.title: Approaches adopted

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Establish formal channels for communication within the organisation, with nonprofits, and the sector. Share your guidelines for multiyear partnerships with nonprofit partners, at group convenings, and in the sector – for examples of how this can be done, see Oak Foundation, Ford Foundation’s Building Institutions and Netowkrs (BUILD) initaitve, and Rainmatter Foundation.

﻿

  1. Create spaces for seeking feedback from internal teams and nonprofit partners to understand the challenges, gaps, and opportunities for multiyear partnerships.
recommended_actions.title: Channels of communication

description: Organisational development (OD) investments build and strengthen a range of critical efficiency and growth-oriented capabilities, such as in strategic planning, leadership and talent development, and financial management, that enable nonprofits to deliver greater impact. Funders that invest in OD help to unlock their nonprofit partners’ impact potential. Research has shown when nonprofits invest in OD, they double their programme output over a three-to-five-year period and became more financially secure. Here’s where your organization ranks on several dimensions of organisational development.
name: vltmcn5a4c

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Speaking to peers who have funded their nonprofit partners’ OD and seek their advice on how to proceed. Leverage learnings from initiatives.


  1. Leverage case studies of how nonprofits have benefited from OD investments, and how funders have achieved greater impact after investing in grantees’ organisational needs, such as Ford Foundation’s Building Institutions and Networks (BUILD) initiative, Oak Foundation and five other European Foundation’s OD investments, EdelGive Foundation’s GROW Fund, and domestic and CSR funders practices on investing in OD, to drive internal consensus.


  1. Engage with OD champions within your organisation to build a compelling case for OD funding.
recommended_actions.title: Policy guidelines

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Taking steps to increase OD budgetary allocation in the annual planning cycle. One can start with seeking feedback on the duration and quantum of funding which can help nonprofit partners invest in their OD needs better, assess the gap between current allocation and requirements, and leverage this to pitch for internal budgetary allocations.

﻿

  1. In case utilization of budget is a constraint, consider adding OD funding to the organisations that receive multiyear support along with program funding.
recommended_actions.title: Annual budget allocation

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Training your programme managers to engage with nonprofits to better understand their individualised OD needs.


  1. In case your nonprofit partners are new to OD, connect them with information, toolkits, and peer organisations to help them learn how to determine their OD needs.


  1. As you extend OD funding to nonprofits, engage them to understand the outcomes of such funding in the short term and and longer term, and identify areas where you can further strengthen your practices.


  1. Document learnings to share with internal and external stakeholders to showcase the impact of supporting OD.


  1. Incase you want to test out the approach, identify collaborative/pooled funds that provide OD support to nonprofits to learn how those investments fared. Learning from piloting OD investments by allocating a percentage of your total funding towards OD grants.
recommended_actions.title: Approaches adopted

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Establishing formal channels for communication within the organization, with nonprofits, and the sector. Share your guidelines for OD with nonprofit partners, group convenings, and in the sector.


  1. Provide training to your grant staff and programme officers to understand the importance of investing in nonprofits’ OD and actively engaging with them to understand their needs based on their impact goals, stage of growth, and programmatic priorities.


  1. If you have chosen to support only specific OD capabilities, clearly communicate these priorities to your nonprofit partners, along with the rationale for the choices. Communicate flexibility that you may be able to exercise, and the criteria for such decisions.


  1. Create spaces for seeking feedback from internal teams and nonprofit partners to understand the challenges, gaps, opportunities for providing support on OD.
recommended_actions.title: Channels of communication

title: Invest in organisational development

description: Financial resilience refers to a nonprofit’s ability to sustain its operations long term and withstand external stresses and shocks, such as the COVID-19 pandemic or the end of a key funder’s support. Nonprofits pursue financial resilience by developing prudent financial plans, monitoring financial performance, diversifying their funder base, and building reserve funds. Funders help by contributing to nonprofit reserves and introducing nonprofits to like-minded funders. Here’s where you organization ranks on several dimensions of financial resilience.
name: ektop2co82

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Revisiting your policy in the context of your impact goals to assess your ability and staff interest in supporting nonprofit financial resilience.


  1. Engaging with your nonprofit partners to better understand their needs and plan for building reserves.
recommended_actions.title: Policy guidelines

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Introducing nonprofits in your portfolio to other funders to help them diversify their funder base.


  1. Supporting nonprofit partners directly or through a financial intermediary to develop a multiyear financial plan that analyses how best to allocate available funding.


  1. Exploring providing financial support to nonprofit parnters, and actively engage with them to understand the outcomes of such funding in the immediate and longer-term.
recommended_actions.title: Approaches adopted

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Establishing formal channels for communication within the organization, with nonprofits, and the sector. Share your guidelines for financial resilience support – both financial and non-financial – extended with nonprofit partners, group convenings, and in the sector.


  1. If you have chosen to provide only non-financial support, clearly communicate these priorities to your nonprofit partners, along with the rationale for this choice. Communicate flexibility that you may be able to exercise, and the criteria for such decisions.


  1. Create spaces for seeking feedback from internal teams and nonprofit partners to understand the challenges, gaps, opportunities for providing financial and non-financial support to build nonprofts’ resilience.
recommended_actions.title: Channels of communication

title: Building financial resilience

description: Core costs, often called indirect costs, involve administrative or support-function expenses not tied to a specific programme, such as salaries of nonprogramme employees, rent and utilities for a central office, fundraising, and measurement and evaluation. Funders that pay a fair share of core costs ensure that a nonprofit is able to conduct its day-to-day operations and deliver on its impact mandates. Here’s where your organisation ranks on several dimensions of core costs.
name: k8gmpe4f02

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Revisiting your guidelines to take into account the full range of costs a nonprofit incurs to do its work. Do not rely on a low, fixed core-cost rate as standard practice. Bridgespan’s analysis of 40 well-funded Indian nonprofits revealed that actual indirect core costs can range from 5 percent to 51 percent, averaging 19 percent. Leading global funders like Ford Foundation, MacArthur Foundation, and The David & Lucile Packard Foundation have overtime, and in geographies where it is legally permissible, either created thresholds greater than 20%, or have completely moved away from having an upper limit on the core cost that they cover.


  1. If lack of clear guidelines is a challenge:
  2. Define your approach to extending core cost support, in terms of percentage allocation, which can help reduce subjectivity across different grants, and communicate this to the relevant internal stakeholders.
  3. Ensure that the organisation’s guidelines are documented and circulated internally.

﻿

  1. If alignment on guidelines is a barrier:
  2. Engage with senior leadership and the board to showcase how core costs contribute to the nonprofit partner’s ability to deliver programmes more effectively. For example, funds used to hire human resources staff strengthen a nonprofit’s ability to attract and retain good talent for implementing programmes. Money spent on technology can enhance finance, human resources and monitoring and evaluation systems. .
  3. Assess whether you are being flexible and supportive within the applicable regulatory frameworks. Under the CSR law, there is no limit on domestic funder indirect costs spending, but there is a 20 percent cap on indirect costs under FCRA guidelines applying to foreign funders. Get legal advice in case you are unclear on the regulatory limits on core costs
  4. Engage with internal and external finance professionals (e.g., finance and procurement teams, auditors, accountants, etc.) to help them develop a deeper understanding of the nature of partnerships and the importance of sufficiently funding a nonprofit’s core cost needs. Be mindful of not engaging your nonprofit partners as vendors, but as equal partners towards a collective mission.
recommended_actions.title: Policy guidelines

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Undertake an assessment of your current core-cost limit against the needs of your nonprofit partner’s actual core-cost needs, and identify whether there is a gap in the support you are extending.


  1. Incorporate a consultative process during the proposal and grant renewal stages to better understand a nonprofit’s core cost needs, and discuss how these costs can enable the organisation to deliver the desired programmatic impact.


  1. Communicate the flexibility that you will extend to nonprofits and your expectations of them, such as a well-structured budget and clear justification of costs.

﻿

  1. As needed, connect your nonprofit partners with third parties professionals to help them compute their core costs. Based on the computation, pay your fair share as a proportion of the nonprofits’s total funding.
recommended_actions.title: Approaches adopted

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Establish formal channels for communication within the organization, with nonprofits, and the sector. Share your guidelines for multiyear partnerships with nonprofit partners, group convenings, and in the sector.


  1. Share the process that you use to establish core-cost support with nonprofit partners to ensure transparency through the grantmaking process.

﻿

  1. Create spaces for seeking feedback from internal teams and nonprofit partners to to reflect on and enhance your core cost policy.
recommended_actions.title: Channels of communication

title: Pay a fair share of core costs

description: The scores for your answers to the 10 DEI practices are displayed on the chart below. The recommended actions provide guidance on how to advance DEI within various stages of your grantmaking.
name: jqs6ccf9g2

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Review your approach to fundng to ensure that DEI goals are clearly articulated and linked to your grantmaking strategy.
  2. Explore participation in pooled funds/ collaboratives that have an explicit DEI commitment.. Evaluate how these channels can expand your reach and effectiveness in supporting more proximate and marginalised nonprofits.
  3. Assess whether your current granteesare working towards DEI objectives. Use methods such as disaggregated data analysis, field visits, and regular check-ins. Do you include proximate/grassroots organisations in your grant portfolio.
  4. Explore possible entry points where DEI can be integrated or further strengthened in your grantmaking by brainstorming with relevant stakeholders.
  5. Use formal and informal checkpoints to assess the effectiveness of grants in meeting DEI goals. Use this feedback to adjust strategies as needed.
recommended_actions.title: Strategic considerations

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Revisit your sourcing strategy and evaluate the mix of ways you identify potential grantees.
  2. Expand sourcing beyond existing networks. Employ strategies such as open-call applications, widespread information dissemination, sector event participation, and referrals from nonprofit partners or alumni.
recommended_actions.title: Sourcing

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Map out the process for grant applications to understand points where nonprofits drop out and why.
  2. Make the application process accessible and inclusive by providing clear information, criteria, and time commitments in multiple languages.
  3. Ensure information accessibility through support such as webinars, one-on-one calls, and assistance with form completion.
recommended_actions.title: Application

recommended_actions.actions:
1. The scores for your answers to the 10 DEI practices are displayed on the chart below. The recommended actions provide guidance on how to advance DEI within various stages of your grantmaking.
  2. Assess whether selection criteria might be too stringent and unrealistic and need to be modified.
  3. Tailor selection criteria to address the unique challenges faced by community-led organisations. Continuously address implicit biases and eliminate unintended exclusionary requirements.
  4. Train the grant selection committee and grant managers on implicit biases, and ensure selection criteria is uniformly applied to all applicants.
  5. Assess the demographic representation of applicant organisations across stages of the grantmaking process, from initial screening to final decisions.
recommended_actions.title: Selection

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Engage with grantees to identify any challenging steps or processes that have affected their experience. Use this feedback to improve the experience for future applicants.
  2. Streamline processes and build relational trust to ease the diligence burden on nonprofits. Consider offering stipends to organisations advancing through the diligence stages to offset costs and recognise their efforts.
  3. Ensure grant officers maintain a trust-based relationship by asking questions respectfully and acknowledging power dynamics.
  4. Maintain rigor in the diligence process whilst fostering a supportive and equitable interaction.
recommended_actions.title: Diligence

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Regularly engage with grantees and internal teams to identify and address challenges, gaps, and opportunities in the grant award and disbursement process that follows grant approval. Use this feedback to make improvements.
  2. Include grantee partners in decision making about grant terms and disbursement schedules to ensure their perspectives are considered and to tailor arrangements to their needs.
  3. Request only essential information and use preexisting data where possible to simplify the grant award process. This reduces administrative burdens on grantees.
  4. Allow flexibility in milestone achievement and customise the grant disbursement schedule based on the nonprofit’s unique context. For example, permit larger initial disbursements to accommodate upfront costs
recommended_actions.title: Grant setup and disbursement

recommended_actions.actions:
1. If you currently do not provide any organisational development (OD) support, start by piloting it for a few grantees.
  2. If you already provide OD support, explore how you can customise it by taking into account the unique challenges that small and marginalised nonprofits face.
  3. Extend support to grantees to enhance their capacity for integrating diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) considerations into their programmes. For partners that are new to this journey, provide them with access to relevant information, toolkits, and network connections.
  4. Speak to peers who have experience with OD funding for DEI to understand the outcomes of such funding.
  5. Provide training to your grant staff and programme officers to understand the importance of investing in nonprofits’ OD for DEI.
recommended_actions.title: Grantee support

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Assess whether the frequency of engagement and the platforms used are equitable and inclusive for all grantees.
  2. Schedule engagements with grantees and key stakeholders throughout the grantmaking cycle to solicit feedback and improve mutual understanding, and engage in discussions about improvement opportunities.
  3. Build and maintain trust with grantees by showing respect, being responsive, and acknowledging power dynamics. Prioritize relationship-building over procedures.
recommended_actions.title: Grantee engagement

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Revisit your reporting requirements and evaluate whether the time and resources required by grantees is excessive. If so, minimise the reporting burden by steps like letting grantees use their exiting formats, focusing on the most critical information.
  2. Send grant officers on site visits and encourage frequent conversations with grantees throughout the grantmaking cycle to expand the way of thinking about reporting.
  3. Continuously engage with grantees to go beyond structured reporting to understand the challenges, gaps, and opportunities they face.
  4. Avoid data collection without any explicit purpose.
recommended_actions.title: Reporting

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Engage in multiyear partnerships with nonprofits, and encourage program officers to look at current grantees to assess whether a long-term partnership might be most fruitful.
  2. How well has the grantee served the interests and specific needs of marginalised communities?
  3. Use progress towards DEI goals as an indicator/metric for renewals or subsequent grants
recommended_actions.title: Renewal
